newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-U.S. has become gold exporter -Gold Institute.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-U.S. has become gold exporter -Gold Institute.

text.p: The United States currently exports about 36 percent of the gold it produces, valued at more than US$1.5 billion, the Gold Institute said on Thursday.
"In 1980, 75 percent of the gold needed by U.S. manufacturers was imported," Paul Batemen, executive vice president of the Gold Institute told the Australian Gold Conference.
"We have reversed the U.S. dependence on foreign gold, and now export over 36 percent of U.S. production," he said,
Over the last 15 years, the U.S. gold industry has invested more than US$15 billion in mine development and exploration, Bateman said.
However, U.S. gold miners increasingly are facing obstacles to growth, he said.
"Much gold has been found on government lands," he said.
"This coupled with environmental issues associated with gold mining, has captured the attention of policy-makers and the media, increasingly with negative results," Bateman said.
At the heart of the debate, is reform of the Federal mining law of 1872.
"The debte is part of a larger struggle over the use of vast U.S. government land holdings in the western states by the mining, logging and cattle industries," he said.
In the U.S., most gold mining occurs on government land, Bateman said.
U.S. gold miners also are becoming increasingly regulated, he said.
"In less than a decade the permitting process in the U.S. has increased from an average 18 months to five years," he said.
Numerous delays and uncertainties in this process, coupled with the increasing threats of punitive royalties and lawsuits are potentially crippling to the U.S. gold mining industry," Bateman said.
The U.S. is the world's second largest producer of gold behind South Africa.
